results.title: Agronomy
results.creator_credit: Jean Palardy, Raymond Garceau and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Describes the introduction of co-operative dairy farming in the eastern townships of Quebec to increase agricultural output and improve marketing methods. Recalls some of the difficulties encountered in the early days of the Agricultural Co-operative of Granby and cites the success of the Granby Co-operative as an example of what can be achieved when agricultural expert and farmer work in close co-operation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Palardy, Raymond Garceau and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Agriculture, industry and power
results.creator_credit: United States Information Agency and Warner-Pathe News
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Describes research into the practical and beneficial uses of atomic energy and radioactive materials in agricultural and industrial production. Highlights Gama rays being used to develop better crop species, radioactive cobalt assisting fertiliser research, atomic energy detecting flaws in castings, checking wear on piston rings and, food preservation, synthetic fuel and electric power applications.

results.title: Agriculture today in Japan
results.creator_credit: Iwanami Productions for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Japan
results.brief_description: Shows the modern methods widely used in Japanese agriculture due to the influence of the country’s increasing industrialisation. Illustrates scientific farming methods, co-operative production and marketing.

results.title: Agriculture in Japan
results.brief_description: Shows the highly organized and productive farming methods of Japan, a small, densely populated country where every available square foot of land is valued. Profiles rice planting and its cultivation, stressing the high quotient of manual labour used in Japanese agricultural methods. The different kinds of produce are clearly defined and their cultivation topically treated.

results.title: Agricultural Collection
results.brief_description:
From the 1940s, the Department of Agriculture’s Film and Video Unit produced film and later video. When this unit was closed, the film and video masters and raw footage were passed to Agmedia. Agmedia produced a range of videos, principally on behalf of the Department until 1996 when it was closed. Ownership of its films and videos (including copyright) reverted to the Department of Natural Resources and Environment (the successor agency to the Department of Agriculture).
The Department of Agriculture’s Head Office Library also operated a film lending service. This was closed in 1993 and their collection of 200+ 16mm films plus videos was placed in storage.
In 1997, following the relocation of the DRNE, the collection was passed to Cinemedia for short-term storage (in controlled atmosphere) for a nominal fee. The collection consisting of 1804 film titles and over 2,000 videos, included:
· The pre 1990 Film and Video Unit master tapes and raw footage;
· The Agmedia masters and raw footage (around 750 films and tapes); and
· The library collection of 16mm films and videos
From many perspectives, this is an important collection, not just because it records Victoria’s agricultural heritage, but also because many of our filmmakers learnt their craft in making these films. There are treasures to be uncovered in the camera original footage.

Ownership of its films and videos (including copyright) reverted to the Department of Natural Resources and Environment (the successor agency to the Department of Agriculture).
The Department of Agriculture’s Head Office Library also operated a film lending service. This was closed in 1993 and their collection of 200+ 16mm films plus videos was placed in storage.
In 1997, following the relocation of the DRNE, the collection was passed to Cinemedia for short-term storage (in controlled atmosphere) for a nominal fee. The collection consisting of 1804 film titles and over 2,000 videos, included:

From many perspectives, this is an important collection, not just because it records Victoria’s agricultural heritage, but also because many of our filmmakers learnt their craft in making these films. There are treasures to be uncovered in the camera original footage.

Agmedia produced a range of videos, principally on behalf of the Department until 1996 when it was closed. Ownership of its films and videos (including copyright) reverted to the Department of Natural Resources and Environment (the successor agency to the Department of Agriculture).
The Department of Agriculture’s Head Office Library also operated a film lending service. This was closed in 1993 and their collection of 200+ 16mm films plus videos was placed in storage.
In 1997, following the relocation of the DRNE, the collection was passed to Cinemedia for short-term storage (in controlled atmosphere) for a nominal fee. The collection consisting of 1804 film titles and over 2,000 videos, included:
· The pre 1990 Film and Video Unit master tapes and raw footage;

results.title: Agora
results.brief_description: ‘Agora’ centres on the fear and panic of being lost in a crowded fairground, as a young girl befriends another lost boy hiding under a bus. The pair cleverly devise a strategy to make themselves seen as well as heard!

results.title: Agonies of nationalism: 1800 - 1927
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “China: A Century of Revolution”.
Documents invasion by foreign troops, the disappearance of the Manchu Dynasty, eruption of the civil war, rise of the warlords, influence of Sun Yat-sen, Chiang Kai-shek, and the threat of the communists.

results.title: Agonia = Agony
results.creator_credit: Elem Klimov, Semion Kutikov and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
In the final days of the Romanov regime (1613-1917), the ‘mad monk’ Rasputin wields power at the court. He is portrayed as a man completely out of touch with the people and political reality, immersed in sexual decadence and the lascivious manipulation of others. The relationship of Rasputin, the Czar and the Empress are explored in this historical drama, with the latter two falling under Rasputin’s spell. Klimov takes a docu-drama approach mixing colour re-enactments of historical events with simulated black and white newsreel footage. This film was completed in 1975 but due to its sympathetic portrayal of Czar Nicholas II, was not released until 1981

Credits: Producer, Semion Kutikov ; director, Elem Klimov ; writer, Semyon Lungin, Ilya Nusinov ; photography, Leonid Kalashnikov ; music, Alfred Shnitke.
Cast: Velta Linei, Alisa Freindlikh, Anatoly Romashin, Alexey Petrenko, A. Romantsov, S. Muchenikov.
